summary:
The reaction p d -> d phi p_{sp} is studied within the Bethe-Salpeter
formalism. Under special kinematical conditions (slow backward spectator proton

the cross section and a set of polarization observables factorize in the
contribution of the pure subprocess p n -> d phi and a contribution stemming
from deuteron quantities and kinematical factors. This provides a theoretical
basis for studying threshold-near processes at quasi-free neutrons.

Abstract
The reaction pd → dφpsp is studied within the Bethe-Salpeter formalism.
Under special kinematical conditions (slow backward spectator proton psp
and fast forward deuteron) relevant for forthcoming experiments at COSY,
the cross section and a set of polarization observables factorize in the contribution of the pure subprocess pn → dφ and a contribution stemming from
deuteron quantities and kinematical factors. This provides a theoretical basis
for studying threshold-near processes at quasi-free neutrons.
PACS: 13.75-n, 14.20.-c, 21.45+v
Keywords: hadron-induced intermediate-energy reaction, meson production,
few-body systems
I. INTRODUCTION

Data of elementary nucleon reactions involving a neutron in the entrance channel are
scarce. One can use, for instance, a tagged neutron (n) beam [1] impinging on a proton (p)
target or a proton beam impinging on a nuclear target. In the latter case one needs models
to deconvolute the pn reaction. Here we are interested in threshold-near meson production.
Over the last decade the data basis for the pp reactions has been impressively improved [2].
Such a detailed knowledge of elementary hadron reactions is necessary for analyzing heavyion collisions. Threshold-near meson production is also interesting for testing predictions of
QCD in the non-perturbative region, provided e.g., by chiral perturbation theory. While it
seems to be straightforward to translate cross sections for reactions of the type pp → ppM
(M is a meson) into the cross section nn → nnM, the channel pn → pnM is less simple
accessible. Model calculations point to a non-trivial energy dependence of the ratio σ(pp →
ppM)/σ(np → npM), e.g. for φ meson production [3]. Experiments showed, furthermore,
a surprisingly large ratio σ(pd → pdη)/σ(pp → ppη) [1,4]. Therefore, it is desirable to test
directly predictions for the pn reactions.
The spectator technique [5,6] offers one possibility to isolate to a large extent the quasifree reaction at a neutron when a proton beam impinges on a deuteron target. Since the
final state interactions in the pn system differs for singlet and triplet states and can be large
1

 at threshold, it is of great advantage to consider the particular reaction pn → dM, as the
deuteron d is in one well defined state. Guided by this, in [7,8] the reactions pn → dM with
M = η, η ′, ω, φ, a+
0 have been considered.
The aim of the present note is to analyze the complete reaction pd → dMpsp and to
test to what extent the spectator technique [5,6] really selects a quasi-free reaction at the
neutron in the deuteron target. In other words, we are going to derive a factorization
theorem showing kinematical conditions for which the total cross section σ(pd → dMpsp )
factorizes in a part depending on the target deuteron characteristics and a part σ(pn → dM).
In doing so we select as a sufficiently transparent example the φ production. The reasons
are obvious: (i) the elementary φ production amplitude is simple [3], (ii) the φ meson is
interesting with respect to OZI rule [9] and hidden strangeness in the nucleon [3,8,10,11],
and (iii) the φ meson is important with respect to both the inclusive K − production [12]
and the e+ e− decay channel to be studied at HADES in near future [13]. An extension to
ρ and ω production goes along the same lines, but due to the role of s, u channel baryon
resonances [10,14,15] the elementary amplitude of the subprocess pn → pnM is by far more
complicate and needs separate consideration, as other mesons too.
Our paper is organized as follows. In section II we present the kinematics, cross section
and amplitudes of the complete reaction pd → dφpsp . Numerical results are exhibited in
section III, where polarization observables are discussed and compared with the ones of the
quasi-free sub-reaction pn → dφ. We also derive selection rules. The factorization of the
cross section is considered in section IV. The summary can be found in section V.
II. KINEMATICS, CROSS SECTION, AMPLITUDES

[6]
pp + pd = p′d + pφ + p′p ,

(1)

III. NUMERICAL RESULTS

From Eqs. (6 - 8), the differential cross section (2) and any other polarization observables
of the process pd → dφpsp are calculable. The BS wave functions uS,D basically coincide
with the non-relativistic S and D waves of the deuteron for small values of the momentum
of the spectator proton (see [17]). Therefore, the relativistic and non-relativistic expressions
for the amplitude F have the same form, and one may perform also calculations by using
4

 deuteron wave functions obtained within a non-relativistic approach. In our calculations we
use the BS solution [18], obtained with a realistic one-boson exchange kernel. Additionally,
Paris and Bonn wave functions are considered to investigate the sensitivity of observables
on the deuteron model.
All our calculations have been performed within kinematical conditions corresponding
to the COSY Proposal #75 [6], i.e., the detected deuteron is supposed to be in the forward
direction and the spectator proton in the backward hemisphere with θp′ ∼ 1200 − 1400. The
momenta of the deuteron are chosen in the range p′d ∼ 1.9 - 3 GeV/c, which means that the
spectator proton is detected with low velocity, i.e., p′p ∼ 0 - 0.04 GeV/c. These kinematic
conditions imply that both the reaction (1) and the subprocess pn → dφ occur essentially
near the threshold.
In Fig. 2, the differential cross section is presented as a function of the deuteron momentum for the specific choice of variables θd′ = 00 , and θp′ = 130o . (We changed the kinematics
with θd′ up to 5o and find a very smooth behavior of all observable.) The kinetic energy of
the initial proton is Tp = 2.69 GeV. The maximum of the cross section at p′d ∼ 2.35 GeV/c
corresponds to that kinematical condition where the momentum of the spectator proton is
maximal, p′p ∼ 0.035 GeV/c. Together with the large spectator angles this implies that
at these kinematical conditions the excess energy in the pn → dφ subprocess is minimal
(∆s1/2 ∼ 4 MeV) and very near the threshold. Obviously, since at such kinematics the production amplitude is almost constant, the maximum in the differential cross section has a
pure kinematical origin being entirely governed by the kinematical factor within the square
brackets in Eq. (2). Fig. 2 highlights that different models for the deuteron wave function
result in quantitatively different cross sections. This is because the integration over the
internal momentum in the final deuteron covers the region of the minimum of the S wave
where different models provide essentially different wave functions (see discussion in [16]).
Let us now discuss polarization observables. Since the spin structure of the amplitude F
M ,M′
in Eq. (8) is basically determined by the spin structure of the amplitude Tsp ,sφn d (νpn , t) of the
subprocess pn → dφ, we proceed with an analysis of this amplitude. Bearing in mind that
M ,M′
Tsp ,sφn d (νpn , t) is a Lorentz invariant quantity one can, for the sake of simplicity, investigate
its structure in the center of mass of the detected deuteron (near the threshold this system
coincides with the center of mass system of two nucleons), provided the Lorentz boost is
M ,M′
performed along the z-axis. In such a case the spin structure of Tsp ,sφn d (νpn , t) is the same as
in the laboratory system (no additional Wigner rotations are needed). Near the threshold,
the final φ − d system is in a S orbital state corresponding to If = 0, JDπ = 1+ (LD = 0, 2),
Jfπ = Jφπ + JDπ = 0− , 1− , 2− , where I, L and J π are the total isospin, total radial angular
momentum, angular momentum and parity, respectively. Thus from symmetry constraints
the allowed configurations in the initial state are Ii = 0, Li = 1, 3, 5 * * * and total spin Si = 0.
The conservation law Ji = Jf implies Li = 1, so that Jiπ = 1− . Hence, near the threshold the
M ,M′
main contribution into the amplitude Tsp ,sφn d (νpn , t) comes from initial spin configurations
with sp = −sn and, since the two nucleons in the final state form a deuteron (with the total
spin S = 1), the most probable transitions near the threshold are expected to be those with
nucleon spin-flips in the corresponding vertices and with the deuteron projections M′d = ±1.
Consequently, the projections of the φ meson are to be Mφ = ∓1.
Coming back to the complete reaction one can expect that the prevailing contribution
5

 into the full amplitude F comes from configurations with Md − s′p = −sp , if (i) the effects
of D waves in the target deuteron may be disregarded near the threshold, (ii) the spectator
mechanism describes the reaction appropriately, and (iii) the factorization (see below) holds.
Hence, near the threshold the polarization observables of the reaction (1) are predicted to
behave in the same manner as the ones of the subprocess pn → dφ. Therefore, the study of
various polarization observables allows to check the factorization.

IV. FACTORIZATION

Let us discuss in more detail the behavior of the cross section Eq. (2) with the matrix
element (8) near the threshold. As mentioned above, the summation over the spin projection of the intrinsic neutron sn in Eq. (8) prevents an exact factorization of the cross
section into the cross section of the subprocess pn → dφ and a "target factor". However,
from Figs. 3 - 5 we conclude that, since the deviations of the exactly calculated observables
from those determined by the selection rules of the subprocess pn → dφ are small, a factorization should hold indeed with a good accuracy. For instance, the asymmetry in Fig. 3
M ,M′
demonstrates the validity of the selection rule sp = −sn , i.e., the amplitude Tsp ,sφn d (νpn , t)
is proportional to δsp ,−sn . Similarly, Fig. 5 shows that the main contribution comes from
M ,M′

transitions with |M′d | = 1, and from the above selection rules the amplitude Tsp ,sφn d (νpn , t)
is also proportional to δM′d ,−Mφ . Hence, near the threshold one may represent the amplitude

amplitude of the process pn → dφ. Then in Eq. (8) the summation over sn disappears and,

reactions at the neutron in the deuteron.
7

 V. SUMMARY

In summary, within a covariant Bethe-Salpeter approach we study the relation of the
tagged quasi-free reaction pn → dφ and the complete process pd → dφpsp near the threshold.
Guided by the very proximity of the numerical results for cross section and polarization
observables based on the exact formulae and on the factorized ones, we find that, for special
kinematical conditions, selection rules are operative immediately causing a factorization
σ(pd → dφpsp ) = F σ(pn → dφ) where F depends on deuteron and kinematical quantities.
This is equivalent to an omission of the contribution of the deuteron D wave at small values
of the spectator momentum.
As an extension of the present work, an investigation of the twice tagged reaction dd →
nnMpsp1 psp2 can be envisaged to study the quasi-free meson production by the nn reaction
proposed in [19].
